newsitem.title: GERMANY: Rheinmetall five-month sales up 24.7 pct.
newsitem.headline: Rheinmetall five-month sales up 24.7 pct.

text.p: German electronics and engineering group Rheinmetall AG said on Friday acquisitions helped sales in the first five months of 1997 rise 24.7 percent to 1.5 billion marks ($887.6 million).
Orders in the period were 1.9 billion marks, 26 percent higher than expected, the company said at a news conference. ($ = 1.69 German Marks)

Not including revenue from Richard Hirschmann GmbH & Co., Rheinmetall sales in the January-to-May period rose 7.3 percent. Rheinmetall on January 1 took over 90 percent of Hirschmann, an electronics maker that had 1996 sales of 530 million marks.
At the end of May, the company had 16,824 employees worldwide, including 2,612 workers from Hirschmann. Without the Hirschmann staff, Rheinmetall's payroll was down 1.8 percent from a year ago.

Previously, Rheinmetall said acquisitions would push 1997 sales to double to about seven billion marks, with pre-tax profit rising to about 100 million marks. It had 1996 group net profit of 45.4 million marks, up from 2.6 million in 1995.
Rheinmetall also recently acquired auto parts maker Kolbenschmidt AG and a stake in defence electronics maker STN Atlas Elektronik GmbH.
